text: Draft offering, black color with tan head that sticks around forever, nose is interesting to say the least, chocolate, marshmallows, roasted nuts, mouthfeel is deceptive, dessert like but full bodied, enjoyable stout all around..

Bitter & dry but overall pretty & smells lovely! Pours nearly black w/ a big tan head & good lacing. The aroma is roasty w/ a chocolate undertone. Taste is a nice blend of chocolate & roast. It finishes pretty dry by overall is quite a nice offering!

12 ounce bottle poured into a brandy snifter. The beer is a dark brown with a khaki head of foam. The aroma has notes of rich chocolate, creme brulee, and malted milk balls. Sweet and chocolaty taste. Bigger body and medium carbonation. Good beer overall.

Growler from The Grove in Yardville, NJ. I thought this was retired, so was surprised to find it. Translucent cola brown color. Small bubbly tan head. Big cocoa dark malt nose. Reminiscent of YooHoo. Flavor is sweet cocoa and spicy hops. Taste is a combination of Tootsie Rolls and herbal hops, with a touch of vanilla bean. Chocolate dominates the palate. More like a Porter than a Stout.
12 ounce bottle. A little light for a stout but still tasty. Not a strong beer, but it went down well. I thought the chocolate aroma was nice

Perhaps they have unretired this one as I just purchased it in a variety case of FF brews......pours a very dark brown with a slight tan head which doesnt hang around long.......aroma of chocolate and not much else, pretty much overpowering......taste is a thick but higher carbed taste of chocolate, very slight booze, hint of vanilla in the middle and finishing with sweet a mild bitterness.

Dark brown rimming beige head; aroma is malt with mild sweetness; flava is rich sweet spicy blend chocolate vanilla pipe tobacco; feels thick foamy creamy; finishes of sweet tobacco and mild chocolate
Pours a dark black with tan head. A roasted malt and chocolate aroma. A strong chocolate taste with grains, roasted malts and some coffee. A lingering chocolate and roasted malt aftertaste.

DATE: January 6, 2017... OCCASION: Friday of a short week needs something strong... GLASSWARE: Guinness pint... pours a dark black body supporting a two-finger light brown head, creamy and foamy like a sponge... nice peat, toasted malts, slight citrus as promised, lactic acids, and earthy coals--not to mention a bit of chocolate... a gritty, grinding abrasive texture on the tongue that vibrates down the throat... a warming smoothness replaces this by mid-glass... at this point, beautiful lacing paints a cirrus sky... chocolate takes center stage, with secondary notes of phenol, scotch-like peat, and light lemon zest... vanilla, lactic milk, and earthiness that produces a lingering sweetness... chocolate, yes indeed--and the "export" stress is appropriated here, with a staunch yet creamy experience at its end... a great example of this style, and a powerful one at that...

Tap at brewery. Actually, Im going against the flow here, I was underwhelmed. Aroma is nice but overall the beer didnt seem well integrated. Although it improved as it warmed, and was good, it never developed into something great. A bit thin for a choco-stout at 7.5% and the chocolate was there, but seemed to fight against the rest ff the beer.

12 oz bottle poured into glass. Pours black with a one finger tan head with nice lacing. Aroma and taste is of roasted malts, chocolate, sweet malts, coffee, vanilla, sweet malts, and caramel. Has a medium body with a creamy, velvety mouthfeel and a mostly sweet, long finish. Overall, a tasty chocolate stout that would be a nice dessert beer.

Dark pour, a thumb of head. Black coffee and dark chocolate aroma. Dark chocolate dominates here, slightly bitter, cocoa, black espresso, sweet but not cloying. Medium to fuller body. A chocoholics beer, especially those that appreciate a good slab of dark chocolate.

Bottle from JT, thanks man! Beautiful thick viscous black pour with two fingers of mocha head. Aroma is coffee, milk chocolate and light hops. Taste is sweet up front, which morphs into some milk chocolate, followed by some roast next up is a light hoppy finish with a semi dry, mild bitter aftertaste. Very nice beer.
Bottle. Pitch black with thin mocha head. Aroma is chocolate and roast. Taste follows and adds some fruitiness. Thick syrupy palate. Ok.

Bottle at home shared with me and myself. Thx Hopscotch. Pours opaque black with a creamy beige head. The aroma is hard roasted malts, chocolate and coffee. Lighter notes of vanilla. The flavor is bitter malty with bitter chocolate and roasted coffee notes. Light body. Bitter roasted finish. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Pours dark brown, almost black, with a medium tan head. Aroma is cocoa, dark chocolate, a little coffee. Taste is medium sweet, more chocolate leading to a bitter, roasted finish. Medium bodied, nice chocolate stout.

Shared bottle. Pours hazy dark blackish brown with khaki head.Nose is roasty dark malt, backup hops, cacao. Tastes of roasty dark malt, cacao, late hops, and some molasses mid-palate notes, I suspect from the nibs.
Bottle pours brown-black with persistent tan head.  Aroma chocolate with slight roast and licorice.  Flavor roast and chocolate, slight molasses.  Mild roasty finish.  Creamy full palate.

Serving: 750 ml. bottle from State Line Liquors.  It pours a viscous black with a thick, frothy, tan head.  The nose is roasty with slight mineral notes.  The flavor has a lot of roasted malt with a slight dark, fruity underpinning.  Those mineral notes show up on the back end with a roasted bitter finish.  A little tobacco emerges as the beer warms.  Full bodied with average carbonation and a long finish.  Tasty stuff.

Pours unclear dark as the Belgian dark chocolate added to the beer, with a caramel head that dissipates quickly. The aroma is delicious roasted malts and toasty chocolate notes so nice in the nose after a few years of development. Flavors have some sweet chocolate boozy notes and roasted malts with developed yeast notes. The body is just creamy and smooth enough.
Dark brown pour with a light brown/tan head. Aroma is roasty chocolate and some lactose.  Flavor is very similar and it is one tasty brew.
750 ml bottle poured a dark black color, aromas of cocoa, roasted malt, dry earth, and some light root.  flavors are the same, light dryness in the aftertaste, decent beer overall.

750ml bottle thanks to daknole 
Appearance: Black with a medium sized tan head and good lacing 
Aroma: Roasted malts and chocolate 
Taste: Chocolate, vanilla and roasty  
A nice stout
Bottle thanks to Craig. Pours a black hue with a medium  brown head. A sweet nose of chocolate and vanilla. A nice smooth brew with loads of chocolate, vanilla bean, light roast, very smooth. Tasty.

Tasted on 4/26/12 from a capped 750mL bottle obtained in a trade.  Pours completely black with a cascading and slow forming average brown head that slowly recedes to a thin layer of lace.  The nose is full of roasted malt and dark chocolate, with just a touch of orange oil, molasses, cocoa nibs, vanilla, milk chocolate, and coffee.  The flavor is lightly sweet cocoa nibs, molasses, vanilla, and milk chocolate up front, moving to dark chocolate and mocha with a hint of orange oil and light bitterness.  The body is full with light but somewhat stinging carbonation and a long vanilla, milk chocolate, and lightly bitter mocha finish.
Bottle. Dark pour with tan head. Dry finish stout with light toasted tones, hints of chocolate. Aroma is dry malt, hints of cocoa, roasted malt and light toasted tones. Flavor follows.

Appearance: oil and pitch under an espresso crema head, tight and creamy, which eventually fades into a thin layer with a slightly thicker border. Swirls thick along the edges.

Nose: chocolate covered dark fruits. Melted European chocolates. Black root followed by char, tar and smoke mingling together effortlessly. Chocolate covered dried cherries. Chocolate covered almonds. Dark fruit tartness along the edges. Dense delicious fudge.

Palate: smooth and silky mouthfeel, gliding across my tongue with a slow persistent building bitter burnt nutty finish. Dark fruits dominate the middle. Hints of red wine and leathery tannins skirt the edges. Chocolate truffle powder in the back followed by a brief hit of peat and smoke. Burnt caramel and espresso crema. Fresh coffee notes fade as the beer warms up, slipping into the background. Grows ever smoother and silkier with each quaff until there is no more. Chocolate is the glue which holds everything together in sublime seduction.

Final Thoughts: yum! Liquid dessert or breakfast. Chocolate and coffee are good anytime of the day as is beer such as the Chocolate Stout from Flying Fish. Thanks to Total Wine for offering Fishs beers here in the sunshine state via a brewery direct connection.

From Beerlicious iphone app: Dark Chocolate and mild coffee aroma.  Black and hazy appearance with a frothy brown head. Starts out with a nice medium bitterness taste and manages to finish heavier.  Medium body with a creamy texture.  Average carbonation with an alcoholic finish.

Capped, 750ml bottle.  Dark  black, Italian roast coffee color.  Dark brown head.  Aroma of heavy roast, burnt grains, sweet florals, charred sugar, dark cocao chocolate, light licorice, sweet vanilla beans.  Deep char flavor, dark roasted coffee flavor, burnt sugar sweetness.  Lingering bitterness resembles coffee bitterness, along with a good amount of dark chocolate and cocoa job character. Hearty character, nice stout, well done follow through with the chocolate notes.  Overall, it is more like a stronger Foreign Stout with chocolate than a Sweet Stout made strong.  I wish this one was easier to get cause it drinks real good.

Bottle. Rich looking dark brown, medium light brown head. The aroma is very chocolatey, with hints of coffee roast and cream. Milk chocolate, burnt malt or light smoke (not sure which), roasted marshmallows, hints of fruit, or maybe just an acidity that pulls my thoughts that direction. Unexpectedly delicious!
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: Flying Fishs Exit 13 has a sweet, roasted aroma with a hint of alcohol in the nose.  Its black in color with a medium-brown head, but thin with a very light body.  Its light on the palate with light chocolate and roasted malts - overall, a very smooth beer.  Theres a hint of light vanilla in the finish that helps smooth out the bitterness of the roasted malts even more.  Robust in the nose, tame in the mouth, and smooth from start to finish.  Excellent example of the style.

750 mL bottle from Ye Old Spirit Shop, Frederick, MD. Pours a nearly black color with a thin brown head. Decent head retention. Aroma of chocolate, cocoa, roasted malts, vanilla. The taste is bitter roasted malts, smoke, chocolate, cocoa, a SweetTart kind of taste, faint vanilla. Bitter hop finish. Medium bodied.

Name: Exit 13 Chocolate Stout
Date: April 07, 2011
Mode: Bottle
Source: Total Wine, Vegas
Appearance: black, fine tan head, drippy streaks of lace
Aroma: rich chocolate aroma, light sweetness brings out a milky chocolate character balanced by a hint of dark choclate
Body: creamy body
Flavor: rich chocolate flavor, sweet milk character, touch of bitter dark chocolate
Overall: its all about the chocolate
Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 8/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 8/10; Overall: 15/20
Rating: 3.7/5.0Drinkability: 8/10
Score: *** /4

Pour is jet black and oily with a small less than a finger thick head. Nose is of of burnt malt and coffee dominantly. Taste is very much like the nose, along with the a strong taste of a nice coffee flavor, though no chocolate presence as well, I guess they saved that for their chocolate stout.

opaque black with a very dense tan head; creamy medium-full body with medium-high carbonation.

aroma: carob, dark chocolate, silage, damp earthy minerality, and a hint of charcoal.

taste: chocolate, charcoal, leafy hops, iron-like minerality, some dark-malt acidity.

Bottle. Poured a black color with an average frothy brown head that lasted and produced good lacing. Good roasted coffee malt and dark chocolate aroma. Medium to full body with a smooth sticky texture and flat carbonation. Complex roasted dark chocolate flavor with a medium to heavy bittersweet smooth finish of moderate to long duration. Very well balanced complex stout.
Bottle. Jet black hue with a light tan head. Chocolate, ash, smoke, and some light booze in the aroma. Light smoke, dark cocoa, ash, and a light sweetness. Medium body thats a little slick.

Bottle Murky black ale with a mid-sized, creamy, cappuccino head. Great retention. The nose presents mocha and vanilla with an undertone of rich, toasted pistachios. Full-bodied with a whole-milk mouthfeel and soft carbonation. The roasty, lightly bitter flavor furnishes notes of cocoa and espresso. Finishes hearty and deeply roasted with a bitch-slap of ethanol and a gentle kiss of cocoa.

Bottle. It poured a very deep dark black with a large (2-3 finger) dense creamy medium brown head that lasted throughout and had exquisite lacing that stuck very well to the glass.

The aroma right off gets you with a nice whiff of chocolate then a moderate roasted dark bread malt and a sweet leathery yeast with hints of dark roasted coffee, caramel, a touch of dark fruit and a tinge of citrus.

The taste well lets just say "WOW" begins with a mild bitterness that has a nice note of coffee, then it progresses into a much sweeter flavor with a large dose of chocolate and a mild fruitiness at the end. The flavor only lasted an average amount of time after the swallow which was rather disappointing since it tasted so good.

Mouthfeel was extremely full and chewy in body with the texture being super creamy and having a nice soft carbonation.

Overall this brew with out a doubt is one of the best beers I have ever sampled. This one definitely makes my top 10 thus far.

bottle pours jet black with a thin tan head that leaves a light film on top of the beer the length of the glass.  Aroma is big cocoa, bitter and sweet with some coffee notes and dark fig and cherries.  Flavor is big roast and ash with lots of bitterness in the form of burnt sugars and bakers cocoa.  The chocolate lingers in the finish for a solid minute.  Good stuff.
Bottle shared by daknole -- thank you, sir!   Pours a dark amber hue with a beige head.  Smells and tastes of malt, toast, faint citrus, bitter cocoa, and cream.  An odd combination, but likable.

Bottle from City Beer. Pours dark brown with an attractive tan head and a treacle and coffee aroma. There is a rich chocolate flavor with a lot of vanilla and a dry slightly bitter finish. Very tasty.

bottle at daks 1/31/11.

dark brick red tinted black shade of brown with a dense tan head.

it smells like barley... more like a grain bag mixed with unfermented wort... along with cocoa, roast, char and a touch of oily vanilla.

the flavor shares the same wort-y flavor... and its pretty dang good... mixed with the other notes from the aroma but mainly chocolate... and lots of it.... but not sweet.

it is a bit on the thick side but rather enjoyable since it is not sweet or sticky! 7/4/7/4/15+
Bottle: pours dark black with a thick tan head, chocolate and malty aroma, taste is malty, chocolate, very dry.

From notes: pours opaque black with a thick, creamy dark tan head.  Has a nice cocoa aroma with a bit of a roasty malt note mixed in.  Medium-bodied, smooth, but lighter than I expected.  Flavor is of chocolate that takes on a bitter chocolate note in the finish.

Bottle.  Pours opaque with an average, frothy brown head, medium-short retention with good lacing.  Aroma is roast and coffee malt, chocolate, light perfume hops, and faint tropical fruity esters and smoke notes.  Flavor is dark malt and smoke with moderate chocolate with light hop bitterness and flavor, medium dark malt bitterness, and a dry finish.  Medium-full body, medium warmth and carbonation.

Nearly black with a thin tan head.  Aroma is sweet chocolate malts, light roasted notes, cocoa, and melted caramel.  Silky smooth body.  Flavor is sweet, lightly roasted malts, chocolate, caramel, and a hint of vanilla.  Smooth from start to finish.  Great beer and best Flying Fish Ive had by far.

Capped 750 from Total Wine in Roseville, CA. Pours very dark brown with a creamy/foamy 4 finger dark tan head which does a bit of lacing. It smells like rich chocolate ice cream. Med body. Flavor is slightly bitter chocolate followed by burnt malt. Very smooth. Quite tasty.

(750ml bottle from Total Wine Desert Ridge).  Pours black with a nice light brown head.  Aroma has loads of dark chocolate, light coffee and some roast.  Taste is sweet with roasty bitterness.  Nicely balanced.   Medium bodied with an oily texture.  Slightly bitter finish.  A really nice beer!

Bottle. Moderate malt aromas of dark chocolate and strong coffee, light perfume and dough for the hops and yeast, with hints of wood, charcoal and candy sugar. Head is small, frothy, brown with good lacing and good legs and is almost fully diminishing. Color is very dark brown. Flavor starts moderately sweet and lightly acidic, then finishes lightly acidic and moderately to heavily bitter. Palate is on the fuller side of medium, close to syrupy in texture, and has a lively carbonation and a lightly astringent finish. This Foreign Stout is pretty tasty and well rounded, but there was an artificial sweetness aspect to it that I didnt care for.
750 bottle-pours a disappearing light brown head and black color.  Aroma is dark malt-some sweet, ashy.  Taste is dark malt-some sweet, ashy.  Thin.

Pours inky black with dark copper edges and one finger of dark tan head. Lots of roasty notes in the bouquet, dark bakers chocolate layered with sweet coffee roast and a mild caramelly sweetness. Rich roasty flavor with a mild acidity and grain bitterness. Notes of coffee grounds and bittersweet chocolate and a mild sweetness. Full bodied with a low carbonation and sustained bitterness.

black pour with big brown head,,aroma of metallic notes, chocolate, roasted malt, licorice and light alcohol. flavor is sweeter than expected, but still gives way to a nice roasty, smoky, chocolate medley. some cream and heavy sugar come through as it warms...as does the same metallic character...this hurts the otherwise good beer

THOUGHTS: Oh dear God, it was wonderful. It was like drinking chocolate syrup. I almost wished I had saved it for Easter. The only problem was that it was a little one sided. Thats not to say it wasnt complex, but it was all very desert like. One of the most intense beers Ive tried this year.
TECHNICAL: Bottle. Poured opaque black (I think thats the first time I actually thought a beer was black and not just really dark brown) with an average to large, light brown head mostly diminished and left good to fair lacing. The aroma was heavy, chocolate milk, milk chocolate, dark chocolate, chocolate cake and chocolate syrup; light to moderate yeast; vanilla; slight alcohol; dark fruit; and slight tobacco when warmer. It somehow was both one-sided and complex. The initial flavor was light to moderately sweet, moderately bitter and lightly acidic; while the finish was moderately sweet, moderate to rather bitter and slightly acidic with an average to long duration. There was chocolate syrup, dark chocolate, yeast, chocolate cake, some dark fruits, slight blueberry, raisin, prune, vanilla, chocolate ice cream, a hint of mint as in mint chocolate chip ice cream or was it chocolate, chocolate chip ice cream. The medium to full body was oily and then a little dry with soft, but tingly carbonation and a slightly chalky finish.
Sampled from a Friday night mini-tasting at Proof.  Just a few notes:  nice milk chocolate and hop bitter taste.  palate on the thin side.  finish is dry.   - 7.2

Black color with a medium sized, light tan head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of roasted malts, cocoa, light smoke, and some vanilla.  Taste of cocoa, roasted notes some coffee, and vanilla, with a sweeter finish.

Bottle thanks to someone who I cannot recall. Pours black with a brown head that dissipates completely. Aroma has notes of dark chocolate and roasted malts with a bit of sweet grains backing. Flavor is similar with dark chocolate and roasted malts with a sweet but dry finish. An interesting beer.
Bottle thanks to mlunger12: Poured a dark brown with a light tan color head. The aroma is chocolate. Taste is dark bakers chocolate with a grittiness to it.

750ml bottle - $9.99 at Total Wine & More in Kennesaw, Georgia.

Appearance: Pours out an inky black body with a medium-large, dark tan head.

Smell: Exit Thirteen smells like chocolate, and, with a bit of roastiness, takes on a slight mocha scent, at least until minute notes of citrus, raisin, and maybe even chocolate-covered cherry join the mix.

Taste: Indeed, its chocolate, semi-sweet in taste, alongside more chocolate-minded malts, a packet of cocoa mix, and some roasted barley. Amply sweet throughout. Slight flourish of coffee-toned roasty malts. Half a drop of Nocello. Light fruity esters and a hint of citrus, but it dutifully, even wisely stays out of the way of the main theme: chocolate. Subtle underlying earthiness. Semi-dry, semi-smooth finish with the booze lending a sip of chocolate liqueur.

Mouthfeel: Medium-full body. Medium carbonation. Tongue-coating mouthfeel like munching on some chocolate squares.

Overall: A tasty chocolate stout! Not as potent or in-your-face as Southern Tiers Choklat or the Rogue Double Chocolate, true, but its still pretty robust, chocolate-wise and has a nice drinkability by being lighter in alcohol.

750ml, red-foiled bottle from total wine in norfolk. pours a deep, dark brown with a short khaki head leaving light rings of lace. aroma is great with huge notes of dark chocolate, fresh fudge, and burnt brownies with notes of earth, roasted coffee with cream, and raw vanilla with hints of toasted malts. flavor is quite tasty as well with bittersweet, rich dark chocolate, smokey ash, roasted coffee, and earth backed by light vanilla, toasted nuts, and cake mix. palate is medium bodied and very smooth with a creamy, almost milky mouthfeel with a long, chalky, roasted finish. overall, a very nice chocolate stout.
Fudge aroma, with hints of prune. Black, thin brown head. Chocolate flavor, cocoa and walnut in the finish. Creamy mouthfeel. Solid and well rounded.

Bottle - 750mL crowned. Midnight black pour with a short, dense brown head. Strong roasted malt, dark chocolate and vanilla notes in the nose. Also black coffee and light molasses in the aroma as well. Taste is biog dark chocolate notes, roasted malt, burnt coffee, oily coffee beans, vanilla and chocolate covered dark fruit. Body is medium with a soft but creamy and dense carbonation. Ends with more big roasted malt notes, dark chocolate, cocoa, black coffee, vanilla, burnt wood and burnt chocolate cake.

750 ml bottle from TheEpeeist. Thanks, Chris. Pours a pitchblack opaque hue, dark and ominous, rich roasty with a pretty dark brown head, moderate sized dies to a solid film, laces pretty well. Aromas are fluffy cocoa, dark and dry with sweet intermittent punches. Cacao nibs, cookies, fairly dark overall with roasty malts, some smoke and earth, touches of coffee, sweet caramel, biscuits, and toast. Rich chocolate, darker and bitter slanted, seems to dominate. Initial is fuller bodied, actually a bit fluffy and creamy up front, a huge blast of cocoa, dry and bitter, roasty and earthy with dark chocolate taking the leading role. Middle throws some sweeter malts, caramel and toffee, roast, toast, with biscuits, moving back into a dry and bitter finish. This doesnt really get sweet at all, the gentle roast and huge dark chocolate, earthy coffee presence keep sweetness at bay, keeping it dry and bitter. More earthy roast, touch of smoke and ash. But big and smooth, really silky on the palate with good roasty and bitter cocoa lingering on. I like this, finish is roasty and lingering cocoa, bakers chocolate, bitter coffee, dry and bitter and dark dark chocolate lingering on. A bit one dimensional in complexity, but silky and smooth, highly drinkable and great for cocoa lovers, staying darker and away from cloyingly sweet sugar.

750ml from Total Wine, Durham. Big frothy pour, swelling and thick. Nose was very dense and sweet milk chocolate, but the taste was thankfully far more understated and dry. With a thick, silky mouthfeel and a slightly chalky finish, this ends up being a quite fine foreign stout, like a modified, choco-fied version of their (admittedly better) erster stout.

bottle.  black with small brown head.  nose is milk chocolate and roasted malts with a nice potency.  flavor of melted bakers chocolate, some milk chocolate, roasted malt.  medium bodied but totally velvety/silky.  very low hop profile which is desirable for this style IMO.  great stuff!!  shouldnt this be a sweet stout?

750 mL bottle from Total Wine in Chesapeake, VA.  Pours dark brown to nearly black with a creamy tan head.  Aroma of roasted chocolate malt with hints of smoke.  The flavor doesnt disappoint; dark chocolate and coffee come to mind most notably but there is a faint smoky element in the background.  The mouthfeel is creamy yet the beer doesnt come across as too heavy (its almost like drinking chocolate milk).  Real damn good.

A: The pour is a very dark brown color with a nice tall brown head.

S: Plenty of roasted malt and lots of dark chocolate.  Theres plenty of a dark fruit aroma to the beer as well.  Maybe a touch of vanilla.  Not really a super complex nose as thats really all there is to it.

T: Plenty of bitter dark chocolate flavors to be found here.  A nice solid roast with a hint of espresso.  The dark fruits are there, but a bit more subtle than on the nose.  Somewhat bitter overall.

M: Medium in body with a fairly high level of carbonation.

O: I was expecting a bit more chocolate flavor, but this was good nonetheless.

3/18/11. 750mL bottle courtesy mlunger12! Opaque black pour with a small ring of chocolate milk colored head. Mild milk chocolate on the aroma with some salty soy, roasted malts, and ash. Big ashy roasted malt flavor that lingers a touch sour with lots of dark chocolate. Not bad!

Poured from a 22oz bottle from Jtclockwork.  Pours nearly black with a tan head.  Aroma is coffee and burnt malt.  Taste is similar to the nose.  Lots of coffee and very little chocolate for a beer described as a chocolate stout.  Decent, but not great.
Bottel courtesy of jtclockwork.  Pours dark brown with a tan head.  Smells of roasted malt, dark chocolate, spicy.  Tastes roasty with some deep chocolate, some roasted malt and a spicy finish.

750ml bottle, shared with the Tallahassee crew, sweet almost coffee aroma, not as chocolate as expected. Very roasty and bitter, a slight sweetiness comes out at the end. Still, more coffee than chocolate. Still very nice.

Location: 750 ml bottle from Buy Rite - Jersey City, 3/11/11


Aroma: The nose is roasted and chocolaty, heavy malty, with just a hint of citrus hops

Appearance: Pours an opaque brown-black color with a small fluffy tan head and spotty lace

Flavor: The taste is roasted/burnt malts and dark chocolate with light sweetness and bitterness

Palate: This one has a fairly creamy mouthfeel, a medium body, and fairly soft carbonation

Overall Impression: 
I like the description of this one as an import/export stout because the area has a lot of ports.  Cleaver guys...  Anyway, on to the beer, I thought this was a pretty solid beer.  Lots of roasted/burnt malt flavor and semi-sweet chocolate dominate this one with some other components as well.  Good stuff.

750mL green glass bottle pours dark darkness with full creamy mocha head with spotty lacing. The aroma does have a pleasing level of chocolate that mixes with black strap molasses, earthy chili pepper meat like notes, a thin layer of burnt toast and faint milk chocolate. The taste begins smooth with a nice level of dark chocolate and quickly picking up near burnt malts and earthiness. Toward about midway a sliver of spicy black licorice comes to the surface for a moment before this slides down a chocolate slide into the finish. Very nice chocolate stout.

Aroma is rich with an overtone of semi-sweet chocolate and tones of quality roast coffee and malt. It pours a beautiful black-brown with a fairly thick, fine-bubbled chocolaty-tan head. Flavor gives the impression of a fine mocha - semi-sweet chocolate and high-quality roast coffee, with a hint of caramel and whispers of wood and apple brandy. Smooth texture leaves a subtle but persistent tingle and a surprisingly hoppy finish, as well as tones of chocolate and coffee. A must for stout nuts!
Very dark blackish brown in color with a fizzy brown head. Smooth roasty malt with hints of chocolate and coffee. More fizzy than thick and creamy. A good, full bodied finish. A nice stronger stout.

Decent sized dark brown head of very fine and dense bubbles.  Rich chocolaty aroma with plenty of roasted grains, a hint of coffee and some raisins.  Color is jet black.  Full bodied and silky smooth palate.  Lots more dark chocolate flavors, mild coffee, blackened toast and some red grapes. Decent amount of bitterness in there also.  Finishes strong and chocolaty with a lingering roastyness.  A decent stout.

Pours a dirty motor oil black, but settles in a dark brown with a tan head.  Aroma of roasted malts, coffee, and chocolate.  Chocolate flavor with roasted malt and hops around the edges of flavor.  Very nice beer.

750mL bottle.  Poured deep brown with a tightly-packed, rich cap of mocha head.  The aroma picked up layers and layers of chocolate.. milkier stuff, semi-dark stuff, slightly smoky stuff, and cocoa nibs.. you get the picture.. vanilla and fresh, complementary piney hoppage around.. moderate roast.. you wont hear me complaining about boatloads of chocolate.  The flavor found the same boatloads of chocolate.. cocoa nibs and milk chocolate at the core with veins of darker chocolate and vanilla throughout.. again the bitterness was complementary, picking up earth to join the pine.. fresh and well-balanced.. very tasty!  Medium-bodied and fairly dry on the palate.. the hops were nicely integrated.. almost a "4" on the palate.

From a capped 750 into a snifter.  Pours a dark, dark black with only a touch of brown head.  Very mild aroma for a chocolate stout.  Whats there smells of leather and cocoa.  Mouthfeel is damn fine.  Not light, not heavy, no syrup, just the perfect combination of light heft and smoooooooth carbonation.  Taste is lightly chocolatey.  Not like chocolate syrup, but more like cocoa and bittersweet chocolate.  Slightly chalky and slightly tangy.  Overall a solid, but not spectacular beer.  FF has raised the bar too high for its Exit series and this one just didnt make it over.

Appearance: Pours a dark brown with a beige head that quickly subsides. Left behind is a thin beige film.

Aroma: Roast, milk sugar and an herbal note.

Taste: Dark chocolate, burnt roast, minerals, and a weird plastic/rubber note in the finish.

Mouthfeel: Full bodied with moderate carbonation.

Overall:  I was disapointed with this bottle. I love chocolate stouts, I loved Flying Fish Exit 1 oyster stout, I didnt find chocolate, and some undesirable off flavors.
Bottle pours black color with a large brown head. Scent is chocolate, roasted malt and coffee. Taste is chocolate, vanilla and roasted malts.

Sampled at the ITAP Big Black Beer Bash.  This beer was as close to black as I have seen.  It was also very smooth and felt like velvet in the mouth.  Very nice chocolate and vanilla flavors were delicious.  Dark fruit and lighter coffee notes rounded this beer out well.  This beer was very tasty but was not over the top.

750ml bottle.  Pours deep dark brown with a 2 finger brown head that left great lacing.  The nose is roasted malt, dark chocolate and raisins.  The taste is roast, ashy cocoa, dark chocolate and coffee.  Medium mouthfeel.  Nice beer.

great chocolate-y and nutty aroma, with lots of vanilla and a bit of anise.
pours opaque brown with very little head.
flavor is a nice mild sweetness, finish is slightly artifical-chocolately, but with some vanilla and roasted grain.
very smooth, very low carbonation

Dark cola-colored pour that gathers to black at its core but remains a translucent mahogany at its edges.  Nice fluffy latte head that leaves large sheets of lacing inside the glass.  Aroma of fudge, vanilla, and cocoa.  Flavor also shows heavy notes of chocolate, caramel, toffee, and again vanilla.  Rich and pretty creamy.  Pretty darn good.

The best thing  about this beer is its aroma which is very chocolate like and its appearance which a nice chocolate hue dark brown lacing head. Taste is a little watery for my liking, Small hint of chocolate maybe but not really. It is very malty and a step above your average stout. It cant even compare to my Founders Breakfast Stout..
Thick black pour, very oily. Chocolate, roasted grain and hint of citrus. Lots of chocolate, roasted grain in the taste. very much a dessert beer.

I dont buy this foreign stout b.s.  This a weak Imp Stout, or just a strong stout.  Its not bad.  Cocoa nose,  All of the flavors are weak but good.  Vanilla and chocolate taste.  Thin palate.  I kinda like it, but it is way too wimpy.  This beer could have potencial.
From a bottle poured a dark brown color with a small amount of head.  Sweet malty flavor with a quick finish, and hints of chocolate.

Bottle  Pours A good dark brown with a creamy rerddish tan head.  The head is froathy and lasts well.  It leaves wonderful lacing.  Aroma is very chocolatey.  Reminds me of chocolatwe milk.  Has some burnt coffee, and a touch of citrus hops.  Has a good carbonation.  The flavor is good and bold.  Nice chocolate base but has subtle flavors of coffee, floral and fruits which dance on the tongue.  Has a splendid mouthfeel.  The texture is creamy and thick.  Alcohol is well hidden.  The finish is good and a very pleasing aftertaste.  A real good beer.

75cl bottle.  Small tan head atop black body with brown edge.  Aroma is moderately sweet, bittersweet chocolate, light floral.  Taste is moderately sweet, bittersweet chocolate, grapefruit, light orange.  Medium-full body, some stickiness, resin.

Pours a deep dark brown, almost black. Almost no head, maybe a few brown bubbles. Great aroma of coffee, chocolate, like walking into a Starbucks.  Taste is roasty, coffee, cocoa.  A little odd finsh.

750 ml bottle from Total Wine - Pours a dark brown color with a 3/4 finger thick tan head.  Faint spotty lacing.  Aroma is a dusty roasted malt and chocolate with a faint hint of smoke.  Flavor is much of the same.  Finish is quite dry.  Medium body.  A nice beer.
Bottle pours deep brown/black with a khaki head.  Aroma shows notes of chocolate, light roast, and a touch of smoke.  Flavor shows the same with additional notes of vanilla and caramel.

750ml, fairly fresh.  Pours extremely dark, almost black in fact, with just a hint of mahogany translucency showing at the edge.  A moderately tall, spongy head of light brown foam slowly recedes, leaving a thin film in its place.  Skinny, jagged cobweb lacing spreads out across the glass.  The nose is quite nicely balanced, based in burnt wheat steeped with loads of rich, bittersweet dark cocoa.  Blackened caramel comes to mind, along with hints of spicy, raw vanilla bean.  Malts are fairly dry overall, working nicely with some lurking earthen hops.  Flavors follow suit, bittersweet from start to finish, never leaning too far towards one side or the other.  Cocoa nibs come forth in numbers, layering the brew with rich, fairly sharp chocolate notes that work well over top of creamy, darkened wheat and well attenuated, scorched caramel malts.  Earthy hops lend a complimentary edge to the cocoa.  The palate is substantive, but not weighty, peppered with a lively, super-fine carbonation that ushers in an increasingly dry, lengthy finish.  Even at 7.5% ABV, the entire bottle is drinkable thanks to the dryness and even-keeled nature of the brew.  Good stuff.
A very bitter beer due to the natural chocolate flavor and less of the hops the malts are solid with only a slightly sweet appearance. Mouthfeel is medium at best. Still good all the way

The aroma is chocolate like with burnt malt, coffee, and hay. The appearance is dark brown with a tan head that is foamy. The taste si like the aroma with a strong bitterness. The palate is average for this style. Overall a good beer but not  a great beer. I wanted more sweetness.

Bottle; poured a dark brown to black with a huge light brown head.  Aroma of caramel, cocoa, roasted oats, must, earth, and wood.  Flavor had a natural tasting cocoa from the outset.  Roasted malt, caramel, earth, with hints of vanilla, cocoa, and alcohol.  Definitely opens up and gets better.
Near black pour with some red highlights.  Aroma of roast, coffee, vanilla and huge chocolate.  Flavor is huge dark chocolate.  Tasty.

Bottle. 25.4 oz. Pours a deep, dark cola brown with a medium, beige, tightly-bubbled head. Small lacing throughout. Aroma of fresh cream, oatmeal, milk chocolate, hints of earth and soil, and some traces of smoke. Medium bodied with a smooth, round, smoky palate. Finishes calm and easy.

750 ml bottle from michael-pollack- thanks again, Pollack! I brought this one to the Big Black Beer Bash 2011. Pours a deep, dark brown, almost black, with a small beige head. Aroma of coffee, roasted malts, earth, bakers chocolate, and some toasted grains. Flavor stacks up pretty much the same, but everything is so mellow, balanced, and smooth. No alcohol is present. Medium-bodied, with a roasty mouthfeel and moderate carbonation. Dry finish. Really nice beer.

Pours black with a big loosely built deep tan head that falls too quickly and leaves little clumps to cling to the glass. Smells of milk chocolate with some roasted malt lingering behind. Also get a tad of dark fruits with some booze. The flavor is nothing extraordinary for a stout. Obviously chocolate is easily recognizable upfront. Dark roasted malt comes in around the edges, but quickly slips into a sweet finish. I am not too crazy about how this beer ends. There seems to be a metallic/mineral like off flavor in the end, on top of a sweetness that is a notch to high. The bottle says it uses dark wheat which may be the cause of such flavors. The body is medium, slightly silky, but not quite as full as Id like a big stout to be.

Bottle shared by phaleslu, thanks Peter!  Pour is near black with a thin tan head.  Aroma is roasted malt, light coffee, light hop, and mild chocolate.  Flavor is very smooth with hints of coffee, roasted malt, light hops.  Very smooth and easy drinking.
Pours dark brown with tan head.  Aroma is chocolate and coffee.  Very sweet with almost a milk chocolate aftertaste.  I was impressed.

750ml Bottle: Pours an oily opaque with a creamy, stringy-lacing froth of beige head.  Has a sweet nutty dark chocolate and cocoa nose with some mild smoke and earthy hops.  Starts with a creamy mouthfeel and lightly sweet toasted caramel maltiness with good cocoa and chocolate flavor with a touch of vanilla and mild roast in the finish.  A well-balanced, drinkable and enjoyable chocolate stout.

22oz bomber served in a tulip pour was three fingers of dark brown head with excellent retention and lacing. Nose was chocolate,coffee and vanilla beans. Taste was coco,malts,coffeee with a light body wow Im impressed with this brew,definitely was not what i was expecting it ranks up their near the best of them for this style.

22oz bottle served in a tulip.  Pour is midnight with three fingers of dark tan head; the brew had excellent lacing and retention.  Nose is roasted malt, dark chocolate, earth, and coffee.  Taste is right on, but the chocolate hides during first impact, then launches forward and attacks the pallet in a very sweet and creamy fashion to comprise the finish.  I really enjoyed the chocolate stout, one of the best Ive sampled, but I wish the chocolate was dominate from first blood till its memory.

Black oily pour dark tan head .... roasted cocoa nibs, chocolatey and roasted coffee aroma .... taste of chocolate, very chocolatey cocoa nibs roasted but mostly just sweet chocolate and vanilla some roasted coffee .... very smooth and chocolatey brew with a dry bitter hop finish .... a great brew

Courtesy of hbmason
Bottle:  The aroma consists of cocoa, roast, and alcohol.  It pours a dark brown, virtually black, with a moderate khaki head that fades to a thin ring around the edges of the glass.  The flavor starts with cocoa and a touch of cream.  The finish turns more to bittersweet dark chocolate and mixes with some moderate burnt flavors.  The burnt flavors are just too strong to be enjoyable.  Medium-full bodied with a somewhat oily mouthfeel.

Courtesy of Pailhead. Black, thin beige head. Roasted coffee, burnt, light chocolate, something really funky I cant pinpoint. Flavor overdone roast, coffee and not much else. Medium body. I really cant get past the aroma.
Brown black, choc brown head, slushy lace. Cocoa powder and dry chocolate aroma; some dates and raisin. Oily, silky feel. Taste is burnt cookie and crumbly choc crust.

Pours black with a chocolate colored head, about two fingers wide. Aroma is of chocolate malts with some bitter spices in the background. Flavor is of chocolate, a tad of sweet vanilla and caramel with a slightly hoppy finish. Medium bodied, quite smooth and roasty, a tad light in the finish though.

Bottle. Pours black with brown head. Nose of roasted chocolate malts, vanilla, freshly brewed coffee and tobacco leaf. Taste is gently roasted chocolate malts, vanilla beans, coffee roast, cocoa and dark wheat. Tasty.

Bomber - Pours like a thick black milkshake with brown head. Fairly intense dark chocolate flavor. Vanilla and cereal flavors also come through. Sweet, with low to moderate bitterness. The first half pint tastes excellent, but the flavor wears a bit thin through the second half.
Bottle pours a deep brown with a creamy tan head.  Aroma and flavor were very similar.  Up front natural chocolate, roasted malt, caramel, nuts, vanilla and light coffee notes.

jtclockwork, thanks! Dark brown pour.  Brown head.  Aroma of roast, chocolate, cocoa powder, and some lactose sweetness.  Flavor is nice and roasty, bitter chocolate, lactose sweetness.  Very nice brew.

Bottle, rating #1300. Pours out black with a moderate tan head. Aroma is of chocolate, cocoa powder and some light roast. Nice, thick creamy mouthfeel. Taste is chocolate, cocoa powder, hot chocolate mix, light sweetness from the vanilla, light roast, a few earthy notes. and some lingering hop bitterness on the finish, but not much. Another home run in the Exit Series, finally some post-Heavyweight beers that NJ can be proud of.

750 ml bottle.  Pours ridiculously oily pitch black with a massive fluffy orange head.  Aroma is big in the fresh chocolate, cocoa powder, cacoa nibs, bittersweet dark chocolate, with vanilla bean, almost has some fruity berry notes, then good roast, and coffee hints.  Flavor is also lots of fresh added chocolate, over the chocolate malts, and roasted barley, lgiht fruity hints, coffee, some vanilla, marshmallow, chocolate oil, then gets a bit ashy dusty and earthy which leads to a nice soft finish.  Very good- still no let-downs from the exit series so far!

tasting.  very dark pour with a thin tan head.  big chocolate nose with a bit of spice.  medium body with thin sides, some chocolate and coffee.  sweet chocolate finish with more coffee and notes of vanilla, nuts and roasted malts.

On tap at Capones.  Dark brown with a beige coating.  Nose is chocolate, mild coffee and hay.  Medium body with a tingle.  Taste is milk chocolate, light espresso, vanilla and seltzer.  Reminds me of an egg cream.  Quite tasty and certainly worth the purchase of a bottle for extended analysis.
750ml bottle. Poured a dark black color with a larger sized tan head. Aromas of chocolate, roasty, lighter smoke and floral hops. Tastes of chocolate, roast, and coffee.

Nearly black, with a dense stable espresso crema brown head, and dense legs on the glass.  Aroma is dark roast and chocolate.  Taste is the same, but has a thin bitterness that misses the mark of luxury. $9/750

Bottle thanks Vic.  Pours a black body with a tan head and slight lacing around the glass and light head retention.  Aromatically malty and citrus.  Light orange and citrus tones, chocolate malt, mocha, and dark chocolate notes.  Has a soft citrus feel, a wet mouth feel and a citrus chocolate body.  INteresting.  Soft with a light vanilla chocolate finish.  Nice offering extra points for bringing something different to the table.

Bottle. 25.4 oz. Split with James and Sean. Pours a deep, dark cola brown with a medium, beige, tightly-bubbled head. Small lacing throughout. Aroma of fresh cream, oatmeal, milk chocolate, hints of earth and soil, and some traces of smoke. Medium bodied with a smooth, round, smokey palate. Finishes calm and easy. Decent stout.

Dark, black coffee-looking pour with a thin, dark brown head. Chocolate aroma is very evident, even with my nose a distance away from the glass. Chocolate smell is intense, but also has a little bit of coffee and dry roastiness to it. Flavor is very balanced, much moreso than other beers that purport themselves to be chocolate stouts. There is definitely a lot of chocolate to it, but its not overly sweet. Nice bittersweet finish. Palate is a little lighter than I expected, but I wouldnt call it thin. Maybe its just me, but I feel like all Flying Fish beers are undercarbonated. Actually quite drinkable for a stout. Really good beer. I enjoyed this a little more than ST Choklat, which made me feel like I had diabetes after finishing the bomber.

UPDATED: JAN 8, 2011 750 ml bottle from Stuff Yer Face. Pours almost black with a nice tan head. Tastes of coffee, bitter chocolate and sweet chocolate. Great stuff.

750 ml from Oak Tree. Yeasty fruit and zest that makes for a sweeter start, but the nose and most of the taste is bittersweet and roasty chocolate. Nicely balanced with a sticky sweet body and a dry clean finish.

Pours deep black in color with a quickly dissipating tan head. Faint chocolate note in the aroma with definite coffee notes. Smooth, medium body with slightly oily and malty mouth feel. More chocolate in the nose than actually comes through in the pallet. Coffee taste with a slightly dry and bitter finish. Enoyable, definitely worth trying a bottle. Solid chocolate stout, not at all sweet. Recommended for fans of stouts/chocolate stouts that arent sweet or overly dry and bitter.

750ml bottle from Chevy Chase in DC.  Pours darkest brown with a large frothy light brown head and solid lacing.  Great chocolatey aroma, roasty as hell with Tootsie Roll like chocolate and slight anise.  The flavor is excellent, rich and chocolatey, a little Tootsie Roll but also dark chocolate and cacao nibs.  The mouthfeel is really drying with medium-full body and some slickness.  Really impressive stout, better than expected.

750ml Bottle:  Aroma of roasted malt, light espresso, Belgian chocolate, slight hops, and slight smoke.  Poured pitch black in color with a large, creamy, dense, rocky, dark brown head that diminished but lasted throughout.  Opaque.  Slightly sparkling.  Good lacing.  Flavor is medium to heavily sweet and light to medium bitter.  Tastes of roasted malt, Belgian chocolate, light espresso, and slight hops.  Medium body.  Thinner than expected, though not thin, chalky, dry texture.  Average carbonation.  Roasted malt, slight espresso, and Belgian chocolate finish.  7.5%ABV is completely hidden throughout.

Bottle enjoyed during a solo craft beer power hour... does that mean something? Anyway, pours a pitch blackish brown body with nice thin chocolate brown lacing. Aroma is mostly roasted malts, with some minor fruity notes and floral hop. Mouthfeel is medium and smooth, with notes of dark chocolate, roast, toffee, wood, and some vanilla.
Bottle. Pours dark brown/black, with a brown head. Aroma is chocolate, roasted malt, and smoke. Flavor is chocolate, coffee, roasted malt and smoke. Medium body.

Bottle from Spirits Brick. Poured a deep dark brownish/black body with a smaller beige tight foamy head.  Aroma of light chocolate, vanilla creamer, coffee and some light decaf chocolte. Flavor of roasty coffee, light chocolate, cola, cream. Yet another winner for FF in the Exit Series, way to represent NJ.

750 ml poured a jet black with a huge reddish-brown head that leaves a nice lacing around the glass. Aroma of dark chocolate, toasted malts, capaccino, and vanilla. Taste is very good with a milk chocalate start and a nice subtle bitter finish. A really great beer!!

Maybe I cant drink chocolate stouts since having ST Choklat.  this one does nothing for me.  Aroma primarily of wet cardboard, with some slight vanilla and roasted malt.  Looks great in the glass, black with a light brown head. Taste is rather bland, with some slight notes of bitter chocolate and malt.  Very slick across the tongue, with a long roast finish.

750 ml bottle.  Pours a pitch black color with a large foamy light brown head.  Aroma of rich baking chocolate, sweet malts, cocoa and a hint of vanilla.  Taste of baking chocolate, sweet malt and cocoa.

1pint 9.4oz bottle pours jet black with reddish brown billowy head.  Aromas of roasted wheat, toasted biscuit malt, a slight roasty sweet malt and vanilla .  Taste is great toasted wheat up front and dark chocolate give it a bitter start balanced with the sweetnees and not overly smokey roasted malt give it a slight sweetness.  Body is medium to full almost wants to be creamy and finish is a good taste that hangs for a bit.  Not to smokey and chocolate is mixed in perfect

Yes indeed, this is a dessert beer. Lots of chocolate. It even looks like a candy bar. Pours an inky black with a velvet tan head that laces nicely. The aroma has some chocolate, vanilla, and nice roast malt. The flavor is similar with a full body and very nice lingering after taste. The flavors intensify as the beer warms.
